directionText: Complete the notes below. Write ONE WORD ONLY in each box.
script: <p><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Directions</strong></span></p><p><span style="color:#000000;">Part 4. You will hear a professor of philosophy giving a talk on the influential philosophy of empiricism. First, you have some time to look at questions 31 to 40.&nbsp;</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="color:#000000;">Now listen carefully and answer questions 31 to 40.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><hr><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Speaker</strong></span></p><p><span style="color:#000000;">Philosophy is the basis of how thought can shape life. And, throughout history, it has played an integral role in some of the world's most revolutionary moments.&nbsp;</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="color:#000000;">Today, I'd like to focus on one transformative philosophy called empiricism. Now, historically speaking, <mark class="highlight-green">㉛empiricism is unique because much of it is abstract and based on theory.</mark> Early empiricism traces back to Aristotle, who lived during the Classical period in Ancient Greece.&nbsp;</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="color:#000000;">Aristotle was the first to introduce the phrase <i>'tabula rasa,'</i> which he used to summarise his belief that sensory experiences shape human knowledge. In English, tabula rasa translates to 'blank slate,' and Aristotle believed that the human mind was exactly that—a clean canvas to be coloured by life experiences. <mark class="highlight-green">㉜Surprisingly, this concept only became widely popular after the 1600s even though its roots trace back to Ancient Greece.</mark>&nbsp;</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="color:#000000;">The main principle of empiricism is called the Principle of Acquaintance and it suggests that we can only have knowledge of things or concepts that we've observed first-hand. <mark class="highlight-green">㉝That is to say that we cannot transfer our own knowledge to other people because everyone has different experiences.</mark>&nbsp;</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="color:#000000;">A famous 17th-century empiricist, John Locke, often referred to as the father of British empiricism, wrote that 'No man's knowledge … can go beyond his experience.' Specifically, Locke argues that we do not possess any knowledge when we are born because we cannot inherit knowledge, so it's up to us to create knowledge through our experiences. <mark class="highlight-green">㉞Locke emphasises that education is only the foundation to being knowledgeable because to an empiricist, 'education begins the gentleman, but reading, good company, and reflection must finish him.'</mark> Using this statement as a guide, we can understand how empiricism has been applied to various fields throughout history, and how it is still practised today.&nbsp;</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="color:#000000;">Take education for example. <mark class="highlight-green">㉟Many schools help students learn by sending them on trips to allow them to have new experiences.</mark> Teachers accompany the students, and <mark class="highlight-green">㉟they usually go to places such as science or history museums.</mark> Similarly, many schools also give students the opportunity to do hands-on experiments in science class to teach them about scientific concepts, which is another way that learning by experience is used in education.&nbsp;</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="color:#000000;">Empiricism is also important in social psychology. A famous exercise called the 'Blue Eyes/Brown Eyes' exercise was created by Jane Elliott in the 1900s to allow people to learn through experience. <mark class="highlight-green">㊱The exercise was carried out to give people the opportunity to learn about issues such as discrimination</mark> by putting them in unfamiliar situations. <mark class="highlight-green">㊲This strategy helped many understand what people from other social groups experience daily by putting themselves in other peoples' positions for a short period of time.</mark></span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="color:#000000;">Empiricism is also prevalent in the business sector. <mark class="highlight-green">㊳It is known that the executives at Duolingo, an online education platform, value knowledge gained from experience as they created an interview process around this concept.</mark> First, all interview candidates at Duolingo are driven to the interview location by designated drivers hired by the company, but they don't know that this car ride is the first step of the interview. <mark class="highlight-green">㊴The executives then gather information on each candidate's personality and attitude by asking the driver how the candidate treated them during the ride.</mark> They gather information from experience, much as empiricists do.&nbsp;</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="color:#000000;">I believe that despite empiricism's long history, it is still applicable to many fields today, and studying it would help us understand how experience plays a role in contemporary society. The beauty of empiricism is that it takes time to understand because each experience builds upon the previous one. <mark class="highlight-green">㊵So, empiricism—in practice—requires time and patience. It is also important for people to be open-minded so that their own experiences don't limit them, but instead help enlighten them.</mark> The empiricists also believe that the most important experiences are the ones that build up the understanding we have of our surroundings and of ourselves, which is a purpose that many people today still relate to.</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><hr><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Directions</strong></span></p><p><span style="color:#000000;">That is the end of Part 4. You now have some time to check your answers.</span></p>
questionBox:
Empiricism

 

Empiricism is distinctive because much of it is grounded in 31 {{blank 1}}.

 

Early empiricism 

  • Principles of empiricism first appear in Ancient Greece.
  • 'Tabula rasa' concept became 32 {{blank 2}} after the 1600s.
  • Our knowledge cannot be 33 {{blank 3}} to others. 

 

British empiricism

  • Experience is the origin of knowledge.
  • We do not possess any knowledge at birth.
  • An empiricist believes that 34 {{blank 4}} is only the foundation to being knowledgeable, but experience is most important. 

 

Influence of empiricism

  • Schools send students to 35 {{blank 5}} such as museums to have new experiences.
  • Social psychology 
    • famous 36 {{blank 6}} created to allow people to learn about certain issues in society.
    • strategy that allows you to appreciate another person's 37 {{blank 7}} for a short amount of time.
  • Duolingo created an 38 {{blank 8}} process to help them gain information from experience.
  • Duolingo's executives learn about each candidate's personality by asking the 39 {{blank 9}}.

 

Relevance today

  • Empiricism requires time and 40 {{blank 10}}, but can help enlighten those who are open-minded.
  • Empiricism teaches people to understand the world as well as themselves.
questionTypeTips:
Question Type: Note Completion 

This question type can be found in any part of the IELTS listening examination and frequently appears in part four. It tests your ability to understand the main points of the conversation or monologue. The main topic is introduced in the heading, and the questions are generally in note form and separated into several sections with their own subheadings. The questions are usually formatted without periods as bullet point lists, but you may sometimes see them presented as sentences.

 

Recommendations & Tips: 

  • Questions that are written in note format may be awkwardly phrased.
  • The correct answer may not always be exactly as it is mentioned in the audio as there may be slight changes in tense or plurality. Instead, the correct answer must be grammatically correct when filled into the answer blank. 
  • Read the directions carefully. The directions tell you to write ONE WORD ONLY, so the correct answer is one word. 
  • Listen for synonyms as the question may be paraphrased using synonyms of the words or phrases you hear in the audio. 
  • Try to predict possible answers before you listen.
  • Use the information that has already been filled out for you in the chart as a guide for following the conversation or monologue while you listen. 
  • Listen for transition phrases or words that help to connect or contrast ideas, or to introduce new information. 
  • Use the section subheadings to predict the information that you will need to listen for.
    • For question 1, you should expect the answer to be a general detail about empiricism because this question is directly under the title and has no subheading.
    • The subheading for question 2 is 'Early empiricism,' so you should listen for information related to empiricism in its early stages. 
    • The subheading for questions 3 and 4 is 'British empiricism,' so you should expect to be introduced to a new type of empiricism called British empiricism, and listen for information about it.
    • The subheading for questions 5 - 9 is 'Influence of empiricism,' so you should listen for information related to how empiricism has influenced people or society.
    • The subheading for questions 9 and 10 is 'Relevance today,' so you should listen for information related to how empiricism is still relevant for people today.
